title: Bristol City launch investigation into their OWN FANS after racist abuse allegations
text:
Bristol City have launched an investigation into their own supporters after allegations of racist abuse during Saturday's Championship fixture at Luton Town.

The club received a complaint that racist language was heard in the away end during their 3-0 defeat at Kenilworth Road.

The Ashton Gate club condemned the abuse and promised to take action against any supporters found guilty.

Bristol City have launched an investigation into alleged racist language used by their own supporters during Saturday's match at Luton Town's Kenilworth Road (pictured)

A statement released on Sunday read: 'Bristol City Football Club has been made aware of allegations of racist language used in the away end at Saturday's Sky Bet Championship fixture at Luton Town's Kenilworth Road (October 19th).

'The club naturally condemns any form of abuse or racist language.

'Bristol City are a family club which celebrates its diversity and inclusivity. Action will be taken against anyone behaving in a racist manner at a Bristol City match, who has purchased their ticket or season card through the club as well as reporting them to the relevant authorities.

'The club are now fully investigating these reports and can assure supporters that appropriate action will be taken.'

Luton also released a statement on the matter saying they would 'support any investigation taking place between Bristol City and the authorities.'

It continued: 'Hatters CEO (chief executive officer) Gary Sweet has already been in contact with his counterpart at Ashton Gate, Mark Ashton, to express our support and co-operation.

Match action from the Championship fixture on Saturday, which saw Luton beat City 3-0

'Like the Robins, Luton Town are a family club that celebrates diversity and inclusion, and will not accept any discriminatory comments or behaviour at our matches.'

Luton won Saturday's match 3-0 thanks to goals by Pelly-Ruddock Mpanzu, Harry Cornick and an Ashley Williams own goal to end City's 10-match unbeaten run in the Championship.

It occurred on the same afternoon that Haringey Borough walked off the field in protest at alleged racist abuse and missile throwing aimed at their goalkeeper Valery Pajetat and defender Coby Rowe by Yeovil Town fans during their FA Cup fourth qualifying round tie.

The match was abandoned after Haringey walked off and refused to play on, the first time such action has been taken in this country.

And the shocking incidents came in the same week that England players Tyrone Mings, Raheem Sterling and Marcus Rashford were racially abused by a section of Bulgarian supporters during England's Euro 2020 qualifier in Sofia.
description: Bristol City have launched an investigation into their own supporters after allegations of racist abuse during Saturday's Championship fixture at Luton Town.
